description: Enjoy a self guided walking tour of Fore Street to see a wide range of public art including murals and sculptures.

factsheet.heading: Fore Street Art Trail 2022 - Self Guided Walking Tour
paragraphs: Enjoy a self guided walking tour of Fore Street to see a wide range of public art including murals and sculptures. It is suggested that you begin the walk at Silver Street Station, taking time on the way back to discover the 100 Angels of the Joyce and Snells.

factsheet.heading: Charlie by AGWA
paragraphs: “Charlie" is inspired by Leeds Street market. The artwork contains a portrait of Charlie. Charlie has been working on Leeds Street Market for 70 years as a greengrocer.
A plantain, okra and pomegranate completes the artwork nodding at the different cultures found around Fore Street.

factsheet.heading: Charlie’s Stall by Doodle Designs
paragraphs: Inspired by the stories of local greengrocer Charlie, as well as contributions from Edmontonians past and present, the murals are influenced by Victoria illustrations, botanical studies and William Morris. The artwork will eventually evolve into a faux ‘ghost sign’ – where text and illustrations of years gone by remain visible, fading over time, contributing to the history of an area.
Quotes from “Charlie’s Stall” by local poet Keith Mowatt also featured throughout.

Imagery taken from both the past and present include crowns and a tun  as a nod to the former public house opposite, and blocks representing the chimneys of Snells Estate Mansion now demolished to make way for the current housing. Transport images through the years are depicted with both horse drawn electric trams as well as more recent mopeds which reflect longstanding hustle and bustle Of Fore Street.

factsheet.heading: Fore Street Bouquet by Hanna Benihoud Studio
paragraphs: Depicting the national flowers of some of the residents of Fore Street, presented as a wallpaper motif in the Joyce and Snell alleyway.

factsheet.heading: Gilpins Bell by Angela Godfrey
paragraphs: Carved from Watts Cliff stone, this sculpture was inspired by William Cowper’s 1782 poem “The Diverting History of John Gilpin”. The poem tells the “true” story of how a wealthy draper named John Gilpin together with his wife and children became separated during a journey to The Bell Inn, Edmonton.

factsheet.heading: A Place We Call Home by King Owusu
paragraphs: For "Enjoy Enfield Summer" festival in August 2020 Artist Hive Studios commissioned local artist King Owusu to create an art mural connecting visual arts with poetry. Titled 'A Place We Call Home', the mural was supposed to be temporary, but the community have been taking care of its upkeep and we’re pleased to see it still in pristine condition today.

For this artwork, local creative King Owusu drew inspiration from the world around him; absorbing references from his family, friends, school and city. King’s illustration was reflective of his perception of the world, deconstructing and rebuilding the world from his own perspective.

factsheet.heading: Sacred Geometry Fore Street by Duo Static
paragraphs: Reflecting the communities in the area, referencing Islamic craftsmen and artists who developed an instantly recognizable aesthetic based on repeated geometrical shapes, where representations of people in holy sites were not permissible.
The artwork and colouring was chosen by the congregation of the of the mosque, bring life to the exterior of the building, reflecting the energy inside.

factsheet.heading: This Is Us and Our Community by Tiger Monkey
paragraphs: Tiger Monkey artists Emma Ghafur, Licia Santos and Delina Kidane worked with 300 children and some parents carers at St John and St James Primary School Edmonton to design this colourful mural.

factsheet.heading: Florence Hayes Gateway by Martin Heron
paragraphs: The artwork comprises a life-size draught horse perched on top of a 3m cylindrical stainless steel plinth looking down towards a bronze cat which reaches up towards the horse. The artist was inspired by Florence Hayes (1879-1956), a charity worker and teacher who was renowned locally for her work with children and animals.
The surrounding metal panels describe the community facilities of the local area over the past 300 years and are the culmination of a local history project with local schools.

factsheet.heading: Portico by T.A. Wilkinson & Frederick Gibberd
paragraphs: Marking the boundary of Enfield and Tottenham is a modernist open portico constructed c.1957.

factsheet.heading: 100 Angels by Tiger Monkey
paragraphs: Tiger Monkey worked in partnership with the local community to create an arts trail through the Joyce and Snells Estate featuring ‘100 Angels’ made and sculpted by local children and residents.
